Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 1: Favored Enemy
feature.text:
You always have the Hunter's Mark spell prepared. You can cast it twice without expending a spell slot. and you regain all expended uses of this ability when you finish a Long Rest. The number of times you can cast the spell without a spell slot increases when you reach certain Ranger levels, as shown in the Favored Enemy column of the Ranger Features table.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 1: Weapon Mastery
feature.text:
Your training with weapons allows you to use the mastery properties of two kinds of weapons of your choice with which you have proficiency, such as Longbows and Shortswords. Whenever you finish a Long Rest, you can change the kinds of weapons you chose. For example, you could switch to using the mastery properties of Scimitars and Longswords.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 2: Deft Explorer
feature.text:
Thanks to your travels, you gain the following benefits.
Expertise. Choose one of your skill proficiencies with which you lack Expertise. You gain Expertise in that skill.
Languages. You know two languages of your choice from the language tables in chapter 2.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 2: Fighting Style
feature.text:
You gain a Fighting Style feat of your choice (see chapter 5, added as feats). Instead of choosing one of those feats, you can choose the option below.
Druidic Warrior. You learn two Druid cantrips of your choice (see the Druid class's section for a list of Druid spells). Guidance and Starry Wisp are recommended. The chosen cantrips count as Ranger spells for you, and Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for them. Whenever you gain a Ranger level, you can replace one of these cantrips with another Druid cantrip.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 3: Ranger Subclass
feature.text:
You gain a Ranger subclass of your choice. The Beast Master, Fey Wanderer, Gloom Stalker, and Hunter subclasses are detailed after this class's description. A subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain Ranger levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Ranger level or lower.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 4: Ability Score Improvement
feature.text:
You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat (see chapter 5) or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Ranger levels 8, 12, and 16.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 5: Extra Attack
feature.text:
You can attack twice instead of once whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 6: Roving
feature.text:
Your Speed increases by 10 feet while you aren't wearing Heavy armor. You also have a Climb Speed and a Swim Speed equal to your Speed.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 8: Ability Score Improvement
feature.text:
You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat (see chapter 5) or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Ranger levels 8, 12, and 16.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 9: Expertise
feature.text:
Choose two of your skill proficiencies with which you lack Expertise. You gain Expertise in those skills.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 10: Tireless
feature.text:
Primal forces now help fuel you on your journeys, granting you the following benefits.
Temporary Hit Points. As a Magic action, you can give yourself a number of Temporary Hit Points equal to 1d8 plus your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1). You can use this action a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain a ll expended uses when you finish a Long Rest.
Decrease Exhaustion. Whenever you finish a Short Rest, your Exhaustion level, if any, decreases by 1.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 12: Ability Score Improvement
feature.text:
You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat (see chapter 5) or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Ranger levels 8, 12, and 16.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 14: Nature's Veil
feature.text:
You invoke spirits of nature to magically hide yourself. As a Bonus Action, you can give yourself the Invisible condition until the end of your next turn. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain a ll expended uses when you finish a Long Rest.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 16: Ability Score Improvement
feature.text:
You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat (see chapter 5) or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Ranger levels 8, 12, and 16.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 18: Feral Senses
feature.text:
Your connection to the forces of nature grants you Blindsight with a range of 30 feet.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 19: Epic Boon
feature.text:
You gain an Epic Boon feat (see chapter 5) or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. Boon of Dimensional Travel is recommended.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 20: Foe Slayer
feature.text:
The damage die of your Hunter's Mark is a d10 rather than a d6.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Ranger Subclass: Hunter
feature.text:
Protect Nature and People from Destruction
You stalk prey in the wilds and elsewhere, using your abilities as a Hunter to protect nature and people everywhere from forces that would destroy them.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 3: Hunter's Lore (Hunter)
feature.text:
You can call on the forces of nature to reveal certain strengths and weaknesses of your prey. While a creature is marked by your Hunter's Mark, you know whether that creature has any Immunities, Resistances, or Vulnerabilities, and if the creature has any, you know what they are.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 3: Hunter's Prey (Hunter)
feature.text:
You gain one of the following feature options of your choice. Whenever you finish a Short or Long Rest, you can replace the chosen option with the other one.
Colossus Slayer. Your tenacity can wear down even the most resilient foes. When you hit a creature with a weapon, the weapon deals an extra 1d8 damage to the target if it's missing any of its Hit Points. You can deal t his extra damage only once per turn.
Horde Breaker. Once on each of your turns when you make an attack with a weapon, you can make another attack with the same weapon against a different creature that is within S feet of the original target, that is within the weapon's range, and that you haven't attacked this turn.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 7: Defensive Tactics (Hunter)
feature.text:
You gain one of the following feature options of your choice. Whenever you finish a Short or Long Rest, you can replace the chosen option with the other one.
Escape the Horde. Opportunity Attacks have Disadvantage against you.
Multiattack Defense. When a creature hits you with an attack roll, that creature has Disadvantage on all other attack rolls against you this turn.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 11: Superior Hunter's Prey (Hunter)
feature.text:
Once per turn when you deal damage to a creature marked by your Hunter's Mark, you can also deal that spell's extra damage to a different creature that you can see within 30 feet of the first creature.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 15: Superior Hunter's Defense (Hunter)
feature.text:
When you take damage, you can take a Reaction to give yourself Resistance to that damage and any other damage of the same type until the end of the current turn.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Becoming A Rogue As A Multiclass Character
feature.text:

Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 1: Expertise
feature.text:
You gain Expertise in two of your skill proficiencies of your choice. Sleight of Hand and Stealth are recommended if you have proficiency in them. At Rogue level 6, you gain Expertise in two more of your skill proficiencies of your choice.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 1: Sneak Attack
feature.text:
You know how to strike subtly and exploit a foe's distraction. Once per turn, you can deal an extra ld6 damage to one creature you hit with an attack roll if you have Advantage on the roll and the attack uses a Finesse or a Ranged weapon. The extra damage's type is the same as the weapon's type. You don't need Advantage on the attack roll if at least one of your allies is within 5 feet of the target, the ally doesn't have the Incapacitated condition, and you don't have Disadvantage on the attack roll. The extra damage increases as you gain Rogue levels, as shown in the Sneak Attack column of the Rogue Features table.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 1: Thieves' Cant
feature.text:
You picked up various languages in the communities where you plied your roguish talents. You know Thieves' Cant and one other language of your choice, which you choose from the language tables in chapter 2.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 1: Weapon Mastery
feature.text:
Your training with weapons allows you to use the mastery properties of two kinds of weapons of your choice with which you have proficiency, such as Daggers and Shortbows. Whenever you finish a Long Rest, you can change the kinds of weapons you chose. For example, you could switch to using the mastery properties of Scimitars and Shortswords.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 2: Cunning Action
feature.text:
Your quick thinking and agility allow you to move and act quickly. On your turn, you can take one of the following actions as a Bonus Action: Dash, Disengage, or Hide.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 3: Rogue Subclass
feature.text:
You gain a Rogue subclass of your choice. The Arcane Trickster, Assassin, Soulknife, and Thief subclasses are detailed after this class's description. A subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain Rogue levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Rogue level or lower.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 3: Steady Aim
feature.text:
As a Bonus Action, you give yourself Advantage on your next attack roll on the current turn. You can use this feature only if you haven't moved during this turn, and after you use it, your Speed is 0 until the end of the current turn.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 4: Ability Score Improvement
feature.text:
You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat (see chapter 5) or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Rogue levels 8, 10, 12, and 16.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 5: Cunning Strike
feature.text:
You've developed cunning ways to use your Sneak Attack. When you deal Sneak Attack damage, you can add one of the following Cunning Strike effects. Each effect has a die cost, which is the number of Sneak Attack damage dice you must forgo to add the effect. You remove the die before rolling, and the effect occurs immediately after the attack's damage is dealt. For example, if you add the Poison effect, remove 1d6 from the Sneak Attack's damage before rolling. If a Cunning Strike effect requires a saving throw, the DC equals 8 plus your Dexterity modifier and Proficiency Bonus.
Poison (Cost: 1d6). You add a toxin to your strike, forcing the target to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target has the Poisoned condition for 1 minute. At the end of each of its turns, the Poisoned target repeats the save, ending the effect on itself on a success. To use this effect, you must have a Poisoner's Kit on your person.
Trip (Cost: 1d6). If the target is Large or smaller, it must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or have the Prone condition.
Withdraw (Cost: 1d6). Immediately after the attack, you move up to half your Speed without provoking Opportunity Attacks.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 5: Uncanny Dodge
feature.text:
When an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack roll, you can take a Reaction to halve the attack's damage against you (round down).
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 7: Evasion
feature.text:
You can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain dangers. When you're subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw and only half damage if you fail. You can't use this feature if you have the Incapacitated condition.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 7: Reliable Talent
feature.text:
Whenever you make an ability check that uses one of your skill or tool proficiencies, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 8: Ability Score Improvement
feature.text:
You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat (see chapter 5) or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Rogue levels 8, 10, 12, and 16.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 10: Ability Score Improvement
feature.text:
You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat (see chapter 5) or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Rogue levels 8, 10, 12, and 16.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 11: Improved Cunning Strike
feature.text:
You can use up to two Cunning Strike effects when you deal Sneak Attack damage, paying the die cost for each effect.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 12: Ability Score Improvement
feature.text:
You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat (see chapter 5) or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Rogue levels 8, 10, 12, and 16.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 14: Devious Strikes
feature.text:
You've practiced new ways to use your Sneak Attack deviously. The following effects are now among your Cunning Strike options.
Daze (Cost: 2d6). The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw, or on its next turn, it can do only one of the following: move or take an action or a Bonus Action.
Knock Out (Cost: 6d6). The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw, or it has the Unconscious condition for 1 minute or until it takes any damage. The Unconscious target repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
Obscure (Cost: 3d6). The target must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw, or it has the Blinded condition until the end of its next turn.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 15: Slippery Mind
feature.text:
Your cunning mind is exceptionally difficult to control. You gain proficiency in Wisdom and Charisma saving throws.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 16: Ability Score Improvement
feature.text:
You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat (see chapter 5) or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Rogue levels 8, 10, 12, and 16.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 18: Elusive
feature.text:
You're so evasive that attackers rarely gain the upper hand against you. No attack roll can have Advantage against you unless you have the Incapacitated condition.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 19: Epic Boon
feature.text:
You gain an Epic Boon feat (see chapter 5) or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. Boon of the Night Spirit is recommended.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 20: Stroke Of Luck
feature.text:
You have a marvelous knack for succeeding when you need to. If you fail a D20 Test, you can turn the roll into a 20. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a Short or Long Rest.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Rogue Subclass: Thief
feature.text:
Hunt for Treasure as a Classic Adventurer
A mix of burglar, treasure hunter, and explorer, you are the epitome of an adventurer. In addition to improving your agility and stealth, you gain abilities useful for delving into ruins and getting maximum benefit from the magic items you find there.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 3: Fast Hands (Thief)
feature.text:
As a Bonus Action, you can do one of the following.
Sleight of Hand. Make a Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check to pick a lock or disarm a trap with Thieves' Tools or to pick a pocket.
Use an Object. Take the Utilize action, or take the Magic action to use a magic item that requires that action..
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 3: Second- Story Work (Thief)
feature.text:
You've trained to get into especially hard-to-reach places, granting you these benefits.
Climber. You gain a Climb Speed equal to your Speed.
Jumper. You can determine your jump distance using your Dexterity rather than your Strength.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 9: Supreme Sneak (Thief)
feature.text:
You gain the following Cunning Strike option.
Stealth Attack (Cost: 1d6). If you have the Hide action's Invisible condition, this attack doesn't end that condition on you if you end the turn behind Three-Quarters Cover or Total Cover.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 13: Use Magic Device (Thief)
feature.text:
You've learned how to maximize use of magic items, granting you the following benefits.
Attunement. You can attune to up to four magic items at once.
Charges. Whenever you use a magic item property that expends charges, roll 1d6. On a roll of 6, you use the property without expending the charges.
Scrolls. You can use any Spell Scroll, using Intelligence as your spellcasting ability for the spell. If the spell is a cantrip or a level 1 spell, you can cast it reliably. If the scroll contains a higher-level spell, you must first succeed on an Intelligence (Arcana) check (DC 10 plus the spell's level). On a successful check, you cast the spell from the scroll. On a failed check, the scroll disintegrates.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 17: Thief's Reflexes (Thief)
feature.text:
You are adept at laying ambushes and quickly escaping danger. You can take two turns during the first round of any combat. You take your first turn at your normal Initiative and your second turn at your Initiative minus 10.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 1: Spellcasting

Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 1: Innate Sorcery
feature.text:
An event in your past left an indelible mark on you, infusing you with simmering magic. As a Bonus Action, you can unleash that magic for 1 minute, during which you gain the following benefits:
• The spell save DC of your Sorcerer spells increases by 1. • You have Advantage on the attack rolls of Sorcerer spells you cast.
You can use this feature twice, and you regain all expended uses of it when you finish a Long Rest.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 2: Font Of Magic
feature.text:
You can tap into the wellspring of magic within yourself. This wellspring is represented by Sorcery Points, which allow you to create a variety of magical effects. You have 2 Sorcery Points, and you gain more as you reach higher levels, as shown in the Sorcery Points column of the Sorcerer Features table. You can't have more Sorcery Points than the number shown in the table for your level. You regain all expended Sorcery Points when you finish a Long Rest. You can use your Sorcery Points to fuel the options below, along with other features, such as Metamagic, that use those points.
Converting Spell Slots to Sorcery Points. You can expend a spell slot to gain a number of Sorcery Points equal to the slot's level (no action required).
Creating Spell Slots. As a Bonus Action, you can transform unexpended Sorcery Points into one spell slot. Copying a Spell into the Book. When you find a level 1+ Wizard spell, you can copy it into your spellbook if it's of a level you can prepare and if you have time to copy it. If you lose your spell book, you can use the same procedure to transcribe the Wizard spells that you have prepared into a new spellbook. feature.name: Level 10: Empowered Evocation (Evoker)
feature.text:
Whenever you cast a Wizard spell from the Evocation school, you can add your Intelligence modifier to one damage roll of that spell.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1

feature.name: Level 14: Overchannel (Evoker)
feature.text:
You can increase the power of your spells. When you cast a Wizard spell with a spell slot of levels 1-5 that deals damage, you can deal maximum damage with that spell on the turn you cast it. The first time you do so, you suffer no adverse effect. If you use this feature again before you finish a Long Rest, you take 2d12 Necrotic damage for each level of the spell slot immediately after you cast it. This damage ignores Resistance and Immunity. Each time you use this feature again before finishing a Long Rest, the Necrotic damage per spell level increases by 1d12.
Source: System Reference Document v5.2.1
